hedline.hl1: Putting Fresh Ads Into a Recorded Show

block.p: The Fox Broadcasting Company is seeking to patent a way to replace ''old'' commercials with ''new'' ones when viewers replay Fox shows they have taped on digital video recorders.

Jon Nesvig, president for sales at Fox, part of the News Corporation, described the technology yesterday at a conference sponsored by the trade publication MediaPost. Fox hopes to test the process, developed by Andrew G. Setos, president for engineering at the Fox Group, with TiVo, Mr. Nesvig said.
The Fox Broadcasting Company is seeking to patent a way to replace ''old'' commercials with ''new'' ones when viewers replay Fox shows they have taped on digital video recorders.

Jon Nesvig, president for sales at Fox, part of the News Corporation, described the technology yesterday at a conference sponsored by the trade publication MediaPost. Fox hopes to test the process, developed by Andrew G. Setos, president for engineering at the Fox Group, with TiVo, Mr. Nesvig said.
Television networks want the Nielsen ratings service to count viewers who use DVRs to record shows and watch them later, as long as three to seven days after the broadcasts.
But advertisers worry about the value of commercials with time elements, for sponsors like movie studios, retailers and automakers, which may be outdated if shows are not watched live.
As Mr. Nesvig described the process, which he called ''time dependent replacement,'' advertisers could ask Fox and TiVo to swap the original commercials for newer ones as taped shows are replayed.
